title: List of state achievement tests in the United States
text:
State achievement tests in the United States are <a href="standardized%20test">standardized test</a>s required in American <a href="Public%20school%20%28government%20funded%29">public schools</a> in order for the schools to receive federal funding, according to the <a href="Elementary%20and%20Secondary%20Education%20Act">Elementary and Secondary Education Act</a> of 1965, in <a href="List%20of%20United%20States%20federal%20legislation">US Public Law</a> 107-110, and the <a href="No%20Child%20Left%20Behind%20Act">No Child Left Behind Act</a> of 2001.
Tests by state.
The following <a href="standardized%20test">standardized test</a>s are designed and/or administered by <a href="State%20education%20agency">state education agencies</a> and/or local <a href="school%20district">school district</a>s in order to measure <a href="academic%20achievement">academic achievement</a> across multiple grade levels in <a href="elementary%20school">elementary</a>, <a href="middle%20school">middle</a> and <a href="senior%20high%20school">senior high school</a>, as well as for <a href="high%20school%20graduation%20examination">high school graduation examination</a>s to measure proficiency for <a href="high%20school">high school</a> graduation. <a href="Nebraska">Nebraska</a> is the only state that does not have a standardized test.
Additional tests.
In addition to the following list some states administer other required examinations. They include Nevada, which administers several tests as part of the <a href="Nevada%20Proficiency%20Examination%20Program">Nevada Proficiency Examination Program</a>. They include the <a href="High%20School%20Proficiency%20Examination">High School Proficiency Examination</a> for Reading and Mathematics; the <a href="Iowa%20Test%20of%20Basic%20Skills">Iowa Test of Basic Skills</a>; <a href="Iowa%20Tests%20of%20Educational%20Development">Iowa Tests of Educational Development</a>; <a href="Criterion-referenced%20test">Criterion-referenced test</a>s in Reading, Mathematics, and Science; <a href="Language%20Proficiency%20Assessment">Language Proficiency Assessment</a>; <a href="Nevada%20Alternate%20Scales%20of%20Academic%20Achievement">Nevada Alternate Scales of Academic Achievement</a>; and <a href="National%20Assessment%20of%20Educational%20Progress">National Assessment of Educational Progress</a>. The <a href="Prairie%20State%20Achievement%20Exam">Prairie State Achievement Exam</a> is used in <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>, along with the Illinois State Achievement Test. Alabama requires the <a href="Stanford%20Achievement%20Test%20Series">Stanford Achievement Test Series</a>; and in Texas, the <a href="Texas%20Higher%20Education%20Assessment">Texas Higher Education Assessment</a>. That state has discontinued its usage of the <a href="Texas%20Assessment%20of%20Academic%20Skills">Texas Assessment of Academic Skills</a>. Since the 2007–08 school year, Kentucky has required that all students at public high schools take the <a href="ACT%20%28test%29">ACT</a> in their junior year.
